pageData.text: This experiment investigates the effects of molecular structure on <button class='glossary-text'>melting</button> temperatures. The student experimentally determines the melting points for 2 organic acids. Next, the student determines the melting point of the mixture of the 2 organic solids. After the data is graphed, the student calculates <button class='glossary-text'>eutectic temperature</button> of the mixture.

3 Snack-size (or larger) resealable plastic bags

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Observe the process of <button class='glossary-text'>melting</button>.
Identify and explain intermolecular forces.
Plot melting point data.
Determine the <button class='glossary-text'>eutectic temperature</button> for a mixture of 2 organic solids.

pageData.text: Soldering is a process used to join different types of components. In this process, a filler metal alloy is melted using a hot iron. This filler metal is referred to as solder. Because of the eutectic characteristic of the solder, the alloy melts and freezes at one temperature. This is an important function of the solder. A common formula for solder consists of tin and lead, however, lead-free solder has gained momentum due to health concerns. Regardless of the ingredients, all solder has an important characteristic: it melts at a temperature that is lower than the components being joined by the process. This is different from welding, which involves <button class='glossary-text'>melting</button> the work pieces. Soldering ensures the components being joined are not damaged during the process. The melting of the solder allows it to flow and contact both component surfaces quickly and easily. Soldering is commonly used in electronics because the tin and lead solder is corrosion resistant and a good conductor. Upon cooling, a strong electrical bond is formed with suitable mechanical strength for electronics.

pageData.desc: A hot soldering iron melting a piece of solder from which fall two liquid metal droplets.
pageData.altText: A hot soldering iron melting a piece of solder from which fall two liquid metal droplets.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Melting</button> is the process of a substance transitioning from solid phase to a liquid phase. The interplay between the kinetic energy of the molecules and the strength of the intermolecular forces between them determines the temperature—and the amount of energy—associated with a phase change.

Electrostatic attraction is the foundation of every intermolecular force. There are several types of intermolecular forces, but they all have one thing in common: they result from the attraction of opposite charges.

<button class='glossary-text'>Electronegativity</button> is the measure of an atom’s ability to attract electrons. As a rule, electronegativity increases as you go up a group and from left to right in a period, as displayed in the periodic table (see Figure 1).

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Periodic table of elements with electronegativity values.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Periodic table of elements with electronegativity values.

pageData.question: Which of the following elements would have the greatest electronegativity?

options.text: An atom of this element easily pulls electrons away from other atoms.
An atom of this element has a difficult time gaining electrons.
This element is found in the first group of the periodic table.
This element spontaneously emits positively charged particles.
Atoms of this element rarely react with other atoms.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Electronegativity is the measure of an atom’s ability to attract electrons. Atoms with high electronegativity more readily pull electrons away from atoms with lower electronegativities.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the electronegativity trend on the periodic table?

options.text: Electronegativity generally increases as you move up and to the right on the table.
Electronegativity generally increases as you move up and to the left on the table.
Electronegativity generally decreases as you move down and to the right on the table.
Electronegativity generally increases as you move right to left on the table.
Electronegativity generally decreases as you move toward the center of the table.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: As a rule, electronegativity increases as you go up a group and from left to right in a period on the periodic table.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Electronegativity is the measure of an atom’s ability to attract electrons. As a rule, electronegativity increases as you go up a group and from left to right in a period, as displayed in this periodic table.

img.alt: Figure 1: Periodic table of elements with electronegativity values.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Electronegativity is the measure of an atom’s ability to attract electrons. As a rule, electronegativity increases as you go up a group and from left to right in a period, as displayed in this periodic table.

img.alt: Figure 1: Periodic table of elements with electronegativity values.

pageData.text: When a chemical bond forms, the difference in <button class='glossary-text'>electronegativity</button> between the 2 atoms dictates the type of bond formed. When the difference is low (or zero), the bond is <button class='glossary-text'>nonpolar covalent</button>. The 2 atoms in a nonpolar covalent bond share the bonding electron(s) equally. As the electronegativity difference increases, a <button class='glossary-text'>polar covalent bond</button> forms. In a polar covalent bond, the more highly electronegative atom attracts the electrons more than the less electronegative atom does. This results in a bond with distinct partially negative and partially positive poles, denoted δ- (delta minus) and δ+ (delta plus), respectively. When the electronegativity difference becomes very large, the bonding electron(s) transfers to the atom with the higher electronegativity, thereby producing ions and forming an <button class='glossary-text'>ionic bond</button>.

Weak intermolecular forces, such as <button class='glossary-text'>London dispersion forces</button>, occur even in nonpolar molecules. <button class='glossary-text'>Polarizability</button>—the ability of an atom’s electron cloud to distort and form a weak, transient dipole—causes this attractive force. All matter is subject to this phenomenon. It is the reason for the correlation between increasing <button class='glossary-text'>melting</button> point temperature and increasing molecular weight.
A polar bond does not necessarily imply that a molecule will have a dipole and exhibit a strong intermolecular force, however. To produce a dipole, a molecule must meet 2 requirements.
First, it must contain at least 1 polar bond. Secondly, the net vector sum of the polar bonds must be nonzero. Figures 2 and 3, with electronegativity values provided, illustrates this.

image.desc: Figure 2: A molecule of hydrogen (H), carbon (C), and phosphorus (P). The H and P atoms each have electronegativity values of two point one; the C atom has a value of two point five. Arrows starting from both the H and P atoms and pointing toward the center C atom indicate there is no dipole in this molecule.
image.altText: Figure 2: A molecule of hydrogen (H), carbon (C), and phosphorus (P). The H and P atoms each have electronegativity values of two point one; the C atom has a value of two point five. Arrows starting from both the H and P atoms and pointing toward the center C atom indicate there is no dipole in this molecule.

image.desc: Figure 3: A molecule of hydrogen (H), carbon (C), and nitrogen (N). The H atom has an electronegativity value of two point one; the C atom has a value of two point five; the N atom has a value of three. An arrow points from the H atom to the center C atom; a second arrow points from the C atom to the N atom. The arrows indicate there is a dipole in this molecule.
image.altText: Figure 3: A molecule of hydrogen (H), carbon (C), and nitrogen (N). The H atom has an electronegativity value of two point one; the C atom has a value of two point five; the N atom has a value of three. An arrow points from the H atom to the center C atom; a second arrow points from the C atom to the N atom. The arrows indicate there is a dipole in this molecule.

desc: Figure 2: A molecule of hydrogen (H), carbon (C), and phosphorus (P). The H and P atoms each have electronegativity values of two point one; the C atom has a value of two point five. Arrows starting from both the H and P atoms and pointing toward the center C atom indicate there is no dipole in this molecule.

Figure 3: A molecule of hydrogen (H), carbon (C), and nitrogen (N). The H atom has an electronegativity value of two point one; the C atom has a value of two point five; the N atom has a value of three. An arrow points from the H atom to the center C atom; a second arrow points from the C atom to the N atom. The arrows indicate there is a dipole in this molecule.
altText: Figure 2: A molecule of hydrogen (H), carbon (C), and phosphorus (P). The H and P atoms each have electronegativity values of two point one; the C atom has a value of two point five. Arrows starting from both the H and P atoms and pointing toward the center C atom indicate there is no dipole in this molecule.

Figure 3: A molecule of hydrogen (H), carbon (C), and nitrogen (N). The H atom has an electronegativity value of two point one; the C atom has a value of two point five; the N atom has a value of three. An arrow points from the H atom to the center C atom; a second arrow points from the C atom to the N atom. The arrows indicate there is a dipole in this molecule.

pageData.text: HCP, a linear molecule, contains 2 equally polar bonds with electron density being pulled in opposite directions. As a result of the linear shape and the equally polar bonds, HCP has no dipole. HCN, also a linear molecule, contains 2 polar bonds with electron density pulling in the same direction. As a result, this molecule has a dipole with the partially negative pole on the nitrogen end of the molecule and the partially positive pole on the hydrogen end.

pageData.question: Isaiah is studying two different molecules. Molecule A has a greater molecular weight than Molecule B. Based on this information, Isaiah correctly assumes that Molecule A has the higher melting point temperature between these molecules. Which of the following phenomena best informs Isaiah’s assumption?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: All matter is subject to polarizability, the ability of an atom’s electron cloud to distort and form a weak transient dipole, which is the reason why increasing melting point temperature correlates with increasing molecular weight.

pageData.question: A non-polar molecule, such as hydrogen gas (H2), still exhibits which of the following?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: London dispersion forces are weak intermolecular forces that occur in nonpolar molecules.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Polarizability is the ability of an atom’s electron cloud to distort and form a weak transient dipole. In other words, it describes the arrangement of electrons, within the electron cloud, around an atom’s nucleus. If more electrons are found on the left side of an atom, the electron cloud will be greater on the left side in order to accommodate the electrons. All matter is subject to this phenomenon. It is the reason for the correlation between increasing melting point temperature and increasing molecular weight. Weak intermolecular forces, such as London dispersion forces, occur even in nonpolar molecules. Strong intermolecular forces, such as dipoles, can be found in molecules with polar bonds. To produce a dipole, a molecule must contain at least one polar bond and have a non-zero net vector sum of the polar bonds.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Polarizability is the ability of an atom’s electron cloud to distort and form a weak transient dipole. In other words, it describes the arrangement of electrons, within the electron cloud, around an atom’s nucleus. If more electrons are found on the left side of an atom, the electron cloud will be greater on the left side in order to accommodate the electrons. All matter is subject to this phenomenon. It is the reason for the correlation between increasing melting point temperature and increasing molecular weight. Weak intermolecular forces, such as London dispersion forces, occur even in nonpolar molecules. Strong intermolecular forces, such as dipoles, can be found in molecules with polar bonds. To produce a dipole, a molecule must contain at least one polar bond and have a non-zero net vector sum of the polar bonds.

pageData.text: When a molecule has a dipole, it will experience <button class='glossary-text'>dipole-dipole interactions</button>. Dipole-dipole interactions are strong intermolecular forces caused by the electrostatic attraction between molecular dipoles (see Figure 4).

pageData.desc: Figure 4: The chlorine atom of an HCl molecule, with a negative dipole, hydrogen bonded to the hydrogen atom of an HF molecule, with a positive dipole. The fluorine atom of the HF molecule, with a negative dipole, hydrogen bonded to the fluorine atom of an FI atom, with a positive dipole. The iodine atom of the FI molecule, with a negative dipole, hydrogen bonded to a hydrogen atom of an H2O molecule, with a positive dipole.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: The chlorine atom of an HCl molecule, with a negative dipole, hydrogen bonded to the hydrogen atom of an HF molecule, with a positive dipole. The fluorine atom of the HF molecule, with a negative dipole, hydrogen bonded to the fluorine atom of an FI atom, with a positive dipole. The iodine atom of the FI molecule, with a negative dipole, hydrogen bonded to a hydrogen atom of an H2O molecule, with a positive dipole.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Hydrogen bonding</button> is a special type of dipole-dipole interaction where a hydrogen atom bonds to a highly electronegative species, such as nitrogen, oxygen, or fluorine. In these cases, the hydrogen atom is partially positive and is attracted to a lone electron pair of a neighboring molecule. Hydrogen bonding is an important component in the structures of DNA and proteins and contributes to many of water’s unique properties (see Figure 5).

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Nitrogenous bases molecular structures and hydrogen bonds between them: adenine, thymine, guanine, cytosine molecules
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Nitrogenous bases molecular structures and hydrogen bonds between them: adenine, thymine, guanine, cytosine molecules

pageData.text: Table 1 shows how these intermolecular forces affect <button class='glossary-text'>melting</button> points. As molecules get longer, melting temperature increases. This is the result of additional <button class='glossary-text'>London forces</button> occurring between molecules. Introducing a carboxylic acid group, which adds the potential of <button class='glossary-text'>hydrogen bonding</button>, increases the melting point drastically compared to the hydrocarbon alkane of equal length.

When a solid absorbs energy, the temperature of the solid increases. The temperature increase results from the increased kinetic energy of the molecules in the solid. Once the melting point is reached, adding energy to the system will not increase its temperature. Instead, the energy disrupts the intermolecular forces between the molecules. As a result, individual molecules escape their geometrical constraints within the solid.

Pure compounds melt across a sharp range. However, as impurities are introduced, they can disrupt the intermolecular forces. This disruption lowers the melting point temperature and broadens the melting temperature range. A binary mixture will eventually reach a minimum melting temperature where the disruption of each other’s intermolecular forces is greatest. This is the <button class='glossary-text'>eutectic temperature</button>.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the effect of impurities on the melting point temperature of a compound?

options.text: The melting point temperature doubles for every gram of impurity present in the sample.
The melting point temperature becomes unpredictable.
The melting point temperature does not change.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Impurities in a pure compound lower the compound’s melting point temperature due to their disruption of the compound’s intermolecular forces.

pageData.question: At the eutectic temperature of a binary mixture, the disruption of which of the following for each compound is at its greatest?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: At the eutectic temperature of a binary mixture, the disruption of each other’s intermolecular forces is at its greatest.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: When a solid absorbs energy, the temperature of the solid increases. The temperature increase results from the increased kinetic energy of the molecules in the solid. Once the melting point is reached, adding energy to the system will not increase its temperature. Instead, the energy disrupts the intermolecular forces between the molecules. As a result, individual molecules escape their geometrical constraints within the solid. Pure compounds melt across a sharp range. However, as impurities are introduced, they can disrupt the intermolecular forces. This disruption lowers the melting point temperature and broadens the melting temperature range. A binary mixture will eventually reach a minimum melting temperature where the disruption of each other’s intermolecular forces is greatest. This is the eutectic temperature.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: When a solid absorbs energy, the temperature of the solid increases. The temperature increase results from the increased kinetic energy of the molecules in the solid. Once the melting point is reached, adding energy to the system will not increase its temperature. Instead, the energy disrupts the intermolecular forces between the molecules. As a result, individual molecules escape their geometrical constraints within the solid. Pure compounds melt across a sharp range. However, as impurities are introduced, they can disrupt the intermolecular forces. This disruption lowers the melting point temperature and broadens the melting temperature range. A binary mixture will eventually reach a minimum melting temperature where the disruption of each other’s intermolecular forces is greatest. This is the eutectic temperature.

pageData.desc: This map depicts the workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. To prepare, set up the heating apparatus and plug 5 capillary tubes. Begin activity 1 by filling a capillary tube with a sample of lauric acid and label the capillary tube.  Next, fill a new capillary tube with a sample of stearic acid and label the capillary tube. Then, secure one tube to the thermometer. Next, heat the water in a glass beaker using the heating apparatus, place the thermometer with the tube into the beaker water, and stir the water gently until the compound has melted. Then, record the temperature at which the compound melted. Repeat the melting process for the other compound sample.
pageData.altText: This map depicts the workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. To prepare, set up the heating apparatus and plug 5 capillary tubes. Begin activity 1 by filling a capillary tube with a sample of lauric acid and label the capillary tube.  Next, fill a new capillary tube with a sample of stearic acid and label the capillary tube. Then, secure one tube to the thermometer. Next, heat the water in a glass beaker using the heating apparatus, place the thermometer with the tube into the beaker water, and stir the water gently until the compound has melted. Then, record the temperature at which the compound melted. Repeat the melting process for the other compound sample.

pageData.desc: This map depicts the workflow for activity 2 of this investigation. Begin activity 2 by creating 3 different mixtures of lauric and stearic acids. Next, fill 3 new capillary tubes with a mixture each and label the capillary tubes. Then, determine the melting point of each mixture. Next, calculate the percent of stearic acid by mass for each mixture. Finally, graph the melting point versus percent composition for the stearic acid data from both activities 1 and 2.
pageData.altText: This map depicts the workflow for activity 2 of this investigation. Begin activity 2 by creating 3 different mixtures of lauric and stearic acids. Next, fill 3 new capillary tubes with a mixture each and label the capillary tubes. Then, determine the melting point of each mixture. Next, calculate the percent of stearic acid by mass for each mixture. Finally, graph the melting point versus percent composition for the stearic acid data from both activities 1 and 2.

pageData.text: Read all instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practice, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

The Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> fuel can contains flammable alcohol gel. Long hair must be tied back and loose clothing kept away from the open flame. The Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can will stay hot even after the flame is extinguished. Use the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can on a heat-resistant surface, such as a stove top or trivet.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

pageData.text: Lauric acid is a health hazard. Lauric acid causes eye and mild skin irritation.
pageData.altText: health hazard symbol

pageData.text: Never pick up broken glassware with your hands—use a broom and dustpan to sweep it up. Place the glass into an intermediate container before disposing into a garbage can.
During the activity, water will be heated to between 40 °C and 50 °C. Handle with care to avoid burns.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area thoroughly with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in a recycling bin.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read the entire procedure before getting started.
Clear a work area for all lab materials.

Place a heat-resistant surface, such as a hot pad or trivet, flat at your work area. Open the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can, and place it on top of the heat-resistant surface. Place the wire stand on your heat-resistant surface so that it stands over the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> with the mesh portion directly above the open can. Make sure there is nothing next to or above this setup as you work through the activity.

The Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can will get extremely hot as the activity progresses. It is important to select a suitable heat-resistant work area so you do not need to move the can. Keep the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can lid and oven mitts or tongs close by in case they are needed. The lid can be placed over the flame to immediately extinguish the flame. Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> fuel can be relit if accidently extinguished.

Take a capillary tube and carefully push a small piece of modeling clay into one of the open ends of the tube to form a plug. Be very gentle when handling capillary tubes as they are extremely fragile and very sharp when broken.

Repeat Step 4 until 5 capillary tubes are plugged with clay at one end. You can gently push the plugged ends of the tubes into a larger piece of clay to hold the tubes upright until you are ready to use them.

This activity has two parts. In the first part, you will determine the <button class='glossary-text'>melting</button> point temperatures of pure lauric acid and pure stearic acid. In the second part, you will determine the melting point temperatures of three different binary mixtures of lauric acid and stearic acid. Finally, you will analyze the relationship between stearic acid melting point and the percent stearic acid by mass of each mixture by creating a graph.
Open the vial labeled “lauric acid.” Use the mini spoon to place a few crystals of the compound onto a weigh boat. Close the vial.

typeBefore.title:
A
  Melting of Pure Compounds (15 steps)

pageData.text: Take a plugged capillary tube and gently push the open end into the compound in the weigh boat. When approximately 2–3 mm of the compound are in the tube, invert the tube taking care that no compound is lost.

Keeping the capillary tube upright, with the open end up, gently tap the tube to settle the compound at the plugged end the tube. If the compound will not tap down to the bottom, you can use a mechanical pencil with 0.7 mm pencil lead to loosen it and push it downward. Extremely gentle side tapping can also dislodge the crystals, allowing them to fall to the bottom of the tube.
Gently push the plugged end of the capillary tube into a large piece of clay to hold the tube upright.

Tear off a 1-inch piece of masking tape, and fold it in half on itself around the capillary tube near the open end to create a label (see Figure 6). Gently remove the loaded capillary tube from the clay, and place it flat on your work surface. Write “LA” on the label. Return the labeled capillary tube to the large piece of clay to hold the tube upright.

pageData.desc: Figure 6: Masking tape folded over the open end of the capillary tube to create a flag-like label
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Masking tape folded over the open end of the capillary tube to create a flag-like label

pageData.text: Return the unused compound to its original container. Rinse and dry the weigh boat and mini spoon.
Repeat Steps 1–6 to load a different plugged capillary tube with stearic acid. Label this tube “SA.”

Gently remove the LA tube from the clay. Use a rubber band to attach the capillary tube to the thermometer with the plugged end next to the thermometer’s bulb. Lay the thermometer/tube assembly flat on your work surface until you are ready to use it. Take care that no compound is lost during this step.
Fill the 100 mL beaker with 50–75 mL of water, and set it atop the wire stand you prepared earlier.
Use a match or lighter to carefully ignite the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> fuel.

While the water is heating, hold the thermometer/tube assembly in the water, with the thermometer bulb/plugged end submerged. Be sure that the open end of the capillary tube is not submerged and the thermometer is not resting on the bottom of the beaker. Continue to stir the water gently with the thermometer, paying close attention to the solid in the tube. Hold the magnifying glass with your other hand to see the solids in the tube more clearly. Record the temperature at which the solid has completely melted in the appropriate cell in Data Table 1.

Remove the thermometer/tube assembly from the water, and let it cool on a heat-resistant surface. Carefully replace the lid on the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can to extinguish the flame, then use an oven mitt to remove the beaker from the wire stand. Allow the beaker to cool for several minutes on a heat-resistant surface.
Remove the rubber band from the thermometer, being careful not to break the capillary tube. Discard the capillary tube in a secondary container, such as a shoebox.
Handle the warm beaker with an oven mitt, pour out the water, and add fresh tap water.
Repeat Steps 8-14 to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>melting</button> point of the stearic acid in the SA tube.
Turn on the electronic balance. Make sure it is set to measure mass in grams. Place a clean weigh boat on the balance, and tare the balance so the display reads zero grams.

typeBefore.title:
B
  Melting of Mixtures (19 steps)

pageData.text: Open the vial labeled “lauric acid,” and use the mini spoon to place approximately 0.10 g of the compound onto the weigh boat. Close the vial. Record the mass in Data Table 1 under “Mixture 1.”
Transfer the compound from the weigh boat to the corner of a new resealable bag, taking care not to lose any compound in the process.
Rinse and dry the weigh boat and mini spoon.
Repeat Step 1 to reset the electronic balance.
Open the vial labeled stearic acid, and use the mini spoon to place approximately 0.10 g of the compound onto the weigh boat. Close the vial. Record the actual mass in Data Table 1 under “Mixture 1.”
Transfer the compound to the same corner of the resealable bag containing the lauric acid (from Step 3), taking care not to lose any compound in the process.

Mix the compounds together by using your thumb and index finger to pinch and rub the corner of the resealable bag from the outside as shown in Figure 7. Be careful not to tear open the corner of the bag as you mix the compounds this way.

pageData.desc: Figure 7: Using the thumb and index finger to mix the compounds from the outside of the resealable bag
pageData.altText: Figure 7: Using the thumb and index finger to mix the compounds from the outside of the resealable bag

pageData.text: When the 2 compounds have been mixed well, pour some of the mixture into a clean weigh boat.
Repeat Steps 2–5 from Activity A to load a plugged capillary tube with Mixture 1. Label this tube “1.”
Pour the remainder of Mixture 1 from the weigh boat back into the resealable bag. Seal the bag, which can then be discarded in the trash.
Rinse and dry the used weigh boats and mini spoon.
Repeat Steps 1–9 to measure approximately 0.20 g of lauric acid and approximately 0.10 g of stearic acid, mixed in a new resealable bag. Record the actual masses under “Mixture 2” in Data Table 1.
Repeat Steps 10–12 for Mixture 2. Label the newly loaded capillary tube “2.”
Repeat Steps 1–9 to measure approximately 0.10 g of lauric acid and approximately 0.20 g of stearic acid, mixed in a new resealable bag. Record the actual masses under “Mixture 3” in Data Table 1.
Repeat Steps 10–12 for Mixture 3. Label the newly loaded capillary tube “3.”
Repeat Steps 8–14 from Activity A for each of the 3 mixtures (tubes 1, 2, and 3), and record each melting point in Data Table 1.
Calculate the percent stearic acid by mass for each mixture.
Create a line graph of the melting point of stearic acid versus the percent stearic acid by mass for all 5 mixtures using either graphing software or the graph template provided.

pageData.title: Disposal and Cleanup
text: Place all capillary tubes, used and unused, in a secondary container such as an empty shoebox or other solid container, then place this container in the trash. Be careful not to break the tubes as they are a cutting hazard when broken.
Discard the used resealable bags and their contents, the used clay, the sealed bags of remaining chemicals, and the extinguished Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can into the trash.
Rinse the used weigh boats and mini spoon thoroughly with water, then let them dry.

pageData.title: Questions
text: Compare the melting temperatures of capric acid and isocane.  Isocane has a higher melting point despite capric acid’s ability to form hydrogen bonds. Why?
Explain why a eutectic temperature is lower than the melting point of either compound in a mixture.
Would you expect citric acid (formula weight = 192 g/mol) to have a melting temperature greater than that of lauric acid (formula weight = 200 g/mol)?  Why or why not?

pageData.content: Figure 1. Electronegativities on the Periodic Table
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Periodic table of elements with electronegativity values.

pageData.content: Figure 2. A polar molecule with no dipole
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A molecule of hydrogen (H), carbon (C), and phosphorus (P). The H and P atoms each have electronegativity values of two point one; the C atom has a value of two point five. Arrows starting from both the H and P atoms and pointing toward the center C atom indicate there is no dipole in this molecule.

pageData.content: Figure 3.  A polar molecule with dipole
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A molecule of hydrogen (H), carbon (C), and nitrogen (N). The H atom has an electronegativity value of two point one; the C atom has a value of two point five; the N atom has a value of three. An arrow points from the H atom to the center C atom; a second arrow points from the C atom to the N atom. The arrows indicate there is a dipole in this molecule.

Figure 4: The chlorine atom of an HCl molecule, with a negative dipole, hydrogen bonded to the hydrogen atom of an HF molecule, with a positive dipole. The fluorine atom of the HF molecule, with a negative dipole, hydrogen bonded to the fluorine atom of an FI atom, with a positive dipole. The iodine atom of the FI molecule, with a negative dipole, hydrogen bonded to a hydrogen atom of an H2O molecule, with a positive dipole.

pageData.content: Figure 5. Hydrogen bonding between DNA nucleotides
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Nitrogenous bases molecular structures and hydrogen bonds between them: adenine, thymine, guanine, cytosine molecules

pageData.content: Table 1. Factors affecting melting points of compounds
pageData.title: Table 1.

pageData.altText: This map depicts the workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. To prepare, set up the heating apparatus and plug 5 capillary tubes. Begin activity 1 by filling a capillary tube with a sample of lauric acid and label the capillary tube.  Next, fill a new capillary tube with a sample of stearic acid and label the capillary tube. Then, secure one tube to the thermometer. Next, heat the water in a glass beaker using the heating apparatus, place the thermometer with the tube into the beaker water, and stir the water gently until the compound has melted. Then, record the temperature at which the compound melted. Repeat the melting process for the other compound sample.

This map depicts the workflow for activity 2 of this investigation. Begin activity 2 by creating 3 different mixtures of lauric and stearic acids. Next, fill 3 new capillary tubes with a mixture each and label the capillary tubes. Then, determine the melting point of each mixture. Next, calculate the percent of stearic acid by mass for each mixture. Finally, graph the melting point versus percent composition for the stearic acid data from both activities 1 and 2.
Figure 6: Masking tape folded over the open end of the capillary tube to create a flag-like label
Figure 7: Using the thumb and index finger to mix the compounds from the outside of the resealable bag

data.title: Dipole-dipole interactions
data.content: Strong intermolecular forces caused by the electrostatic attraction between molecular dipoles

data.title: Electronegativity
data.content: The measure of an atom’s ability to attract electrons

data.title: Eutectic temperature
data.content: The minimum melting temperature of a binary mixture, at which point the disruption of each compound’s intermolecular forces is greatest

data.title: Hydrogen bonding
data.content: A special type of dipole-dipole interaction where a hydrogen atom bonds to a highly electronegative species such as nitrogen, oxygen, or fluorine

data.title: Ionic bond
data.content: The chemical bond that forms when the electronegativity difference between two atoms is very large, causing the bonding electron(s) to transfer to the atom with the higher electronegativity; the atoms in this type of bond exist as ions

data.title: London dispersion forces
data.content: Weak intermolecular forces that exist in all compounds

data.title: Melting
data.content: The process of a substance transitioning from solid phase to liquid phase

data.title: Nonpolar covalent
data.content: The chemical bond that forms when the electronegativity difference between two atoms is low or zero, causing the bonding electron(s) to be shared equally between the atoms

data.title: Polar covalent bond
data.content: The chemical bond that forms between two atoms of differing electronegativities when the more electronegative atom sees the shared electrons more than does the less electronegative atom; this type of bond has partially negative and partially positive poles, denoted δ- (delta minus) and δ+ (delta plus), respectively

data.title: Polarizability
data.content: The ability of an atom’s electron cloud to distort and form a weak, transient dipole
